content: Classic Disney movie and one of my absolute favorites hands down!!! It never gets old and always brings me back to my childhood. Magical!

title: The Most Enchaning One of All
content: Cinderella is my favorite Disney movie of all time. The music is great, the animation, and lets not forget the characters, I like Cinderella most of all, because Cinderella is like a drama. The setting is beautiful, and the music just makes it even better. My favorite sequence is the Nightengale sequence when she's cleaning the floor, although short that sequence takes the viewer inside Cinderellas mind, even for asceond. Until Lucifer starts trouble and Cinderella is brung back to reality (which she faces everyday). Another thing, although these parts only happen once in the movie, Cinderella coming down in the morning, the viewer gets the idea of what her life really is. She comes down, and starts the day off dreaming into her own fantasy world. Thats why Cinderella is so special. Sleeping Beauty has Aurora dancing in the forest, but thats all we would know about her, the viewer doesn't know what her life is like living in a cottage in a great forest, Cinderella reveals all these things, and thats what really gets the audience, captivation, mystery, and drama(the stepmother scene) Expecially the stepmother scene. I mean other scenes have the villain look terrifying by making them look grotesque or ugly like Snow Whites witch, but Cinderella has the stepmother be scary by her attitude toward things, shes strict and I dont know about anyone else but when I used to watch that part of the movie I was really into it, I mean all attention was captured by that scene. Cinderella is I think one of the best Disney movies.

title: Funny but also moving
content: Part of the genius of this movie is telling Cinderella's story indirectly. To focus on Cinderella's life would be too depressing and dark. Instead, we watch slapstick comedy with mice, birds, a cat and a dog for most of the movie, only observing Cinderella in the background. The details are easy to miss for a child as I usually did - I was too busy engaged, smiling and laughing. But now I see the way she is treated, like she's not even a human being.Eventually, Cinderella breaks down. I found that very moving because it's not just about her dress or going to a ball. She's given up hope. As she sobs, she says: "It's just no use. No use at all. I can't believe. Not any more. There's nothing left to believe in." It's heartbreaking. Not even the animals can cheer her up - they don't know what to do. It's a place most of us don't want to be but I think most of us have been there.And only then does it hit you how positive and strong she's been. She took everything in her stride, happily singing, smiling and dancing while basically living as a slave. All that happiness suddenly disappears and we feel the true despair she is facing. Of course, the movie turns magical after that, which makes us feel good, but we know that it's pure fantasy.Cinderella's innocence and joy are what make her special. The prince is bored by an endless slew of suitresses, but is immediately drawn to Cinderella. She experiences true happiness for once as she dances with him. But in a way she'd always been this happy because she's always dreamed about this and completely believed in it. We don't have to dream of meeting prince charming, but I think it's good to dream about something and aim for it. The dream can help us focus and endure hardships. Afterwards, she's in a trance - that deep kind of satisfied happiness which can last for days or weeks.There are a lot of hilarious double-takes. The dog runs in his sleep, bites the rug and awakens. Cinderella asks if the dog has been dreaming. He nods. She asks if he was chasing the cat. He smiles and keeps nodding. She asks if he caught him this time. The smiling and nodding intensifies. Suddenly she says "that's bad" with an abrupt change in the music and it's like he's been whacked on the head. He is utterly confused as to why this could be "bad". There are many moments like this which are perfectly executed and make me laugh out loud.Later, the cat is ferociously looking under cups to find a mouse. Eventually, he's so excited that he doesn't even notice the mouse under the first cup he checks. Once he realises, he's bursting with excitement to eat the mouse but it's too late because Cinderella's coming back. He nearly dies from frustration as he slinks back under the table. I find these subtle details hilarious. And the final climax of the movie has real excitement with a mix of comedy and tension.Cinderella is a classic. The story is simple but it works on every level. It's heartwarming and entertaining - among the best Disney films.

title: All Politics aside, It's still a beautiful masterpiece.
content: The Moral of Cinderella, however you put it, isn't the most realistic moral."No matter how your heart is grieving, if you keep on believing, the dream that you wish will come true".Cute, but that's not going to do Anne Frank any good.But I believe It's more about being optimistic; not so much, you get what you want because of Karma.The film is beautiful, exciting with interesting characters (I'm dead serious, Cinderella is a very interesting character).I don't care how many movies you've seen.That Climax is one of the most exciting of any Disney film.

title: The word "if" is doing a lot of heavy lifting in that sentence
content: Another of the classic animated Disney adaptations of fairy tales.The animation is excellent, with strong use of colour, effective visual communication and significant personality, not to mention impossibly smooth movements to all the characters. The music is catchy, the script shows a firm grasp on the crucial concepts of set up and pay off, there's humour, cuteness, tension and action, all of it works well - a gag where Lucifer, the hungry cat, looks for a mouse in three teacups that are placed upside down combines all of these. It's no wonder this has been re-watched countless times over the decades.What this has brought to pop culture has gone over a few reassessments over the 73 years since it premiered. Originally, it was seen as a positive depiction of how young ladies should behave. Cinderella herself is passive and largely accepts her bad situation. She does all the hard work that she's forced to do, despite it being clear from the start that it is extremely unfair. She doesn't seek out political power or try to subvert the situation in which she finds herself, like the suffragettes did. More than anything, she wants romance and other positive social experiences. It's seen as perfectly good that the king wants for his son to marry, and it doesn't really matter for him to who, as long as she is upper class. Love is presented as purely the honeymoon phase, with none of the complicated aspects that come later. By today's standards, this all feels very limiting, and mired in respectability politics.However, as has more recently been pointed out, part of why she is a good role model is the fact that she refuses to let her bullies turn her into an abuser herself. She has the power to be cruel to the small animals that frequent her room, but instead treats them with the kind of compassion and empathy that they and she deserve. She's a good communicator and lives in happy communion with the parts of nature that she is able to, tending to their needs. She is kind, patient and shows gratitude when others do help her. Before things get better, the first step is her truly imagining things could improve, rather than giving up all hope. These are stereotypes about women common to patriarchal systems, and absolutely should not be seen as the only thing that they are able to do, or allowed to do, much less that it is a problem if they do not adhere to these. On the other hand, these are not actually negative like many misogynist tropes about the nature of the fairer sex, that paint them as terrible, demands that they behave a certain way, punishing them *whether they do or not*, and then these man children will turn around and scream about how it doesn't make any sense that they can't find someone who can stand being around them. Crisis of masculinity? Largely self-inflicted. Anyway. These traits could easily be emulated by gals today if they so choose.The step family is entirely made up of females making the point that sometimes they can be awful to their own, and that this is behaviour that should be avoided. Heck, they are basically a trio of girlbosses. It is of course really messed up that among the stuff that's bad about them is they aren't conventionally attractive and show no musical talents. They are by far the most selfish, though at least they aren't the only foolish and shallow people in this. It is very cis hetero, for example in an early bit where the idea that a boy couldn't wear a dress is treated as the most obvious thing in the world. Still, it does present a world where both parts of the gender binary, at least if they're birds and mice, can work together even on something like making a dress, rather than encouraging separating them, and insisting that they are too different to peacefully coexist.This features some disturbing content. I recommend this to everyone. 8/10.

title: Pure magical classic!!!
content: Just perfect !! Beautifully drawn animation and delightful music is what that makes this classic unforgettable.

title: Not quite a full-blown classic, but still one of Disney's better efforts...
content: Personally, CINDERELLA seems a tad redundant... there's simply a few too many Disney features that concern a female title character who is "saved" at the end by some sort of Prince.  SNOW WHITE AND THE SEVEN DWARFS (1937) had already come before CINDERELLA (1950), and SLEEPING BEAUTY (1959) seemed like a "greatest hits" version of both movies.  And in the grand scheme of all things Disney, CINDERELLA, overall, is probably not one of the greatest features Walt oversaw (props should rightfully go to other efforts such as FANTASIA, SNOW WHITE, PINOCCHIO, BAMBI and DUMBO).  But before I get too stuffy about all this...CINDERELLA is still funny, charming and loaded with fun songs and absolutely superb animation.  If I only have one minor quibble, it's that the business between the mice and Lucifer the cat seem to take up a little too much time of the film.  If you have children, or are simply a fan of old movies or animation in general, no collection is complete without this.  It may not be perfect, but it comes closer than most animated films of today and is still a minor classic at the very least.

title: Another one of Disney's classics-Dazzling
content: Cinderella is a beautiful film, with beautiful songs of course. In fact, it's one of the best films of the 1950's.I think all the characters are portrayed amazingly. You can see the cruelness of Cinderella's stepsisters and her stepmother, the sweetness of Cinderella. The mice are funny and sweet too.I think they changed the tale a bit, but I think it's for the best. It's such a nice film, and I don't think anyone could resist it deep down.I give it a 8/10. I don't think it's the best Disney film. But it sure is a true classic.

title: The Best Disney has made up to that point
content: This was the film that saved Disney's Studios and enabled it to be a cultural institution. It made so much money that Disney was able to pay off their debt, finance most of their productions in the 1950s, and start to build Disney World. Despite a few artistic successes, most of the films released in the previous decade by the company had been both commercial and artistic flops. What makes this film so good? The first striking thing is that Cinderella is actually a real, believable character who makes choices and has wants and desires. This is in contrast to Snow White, who was just singing with birds all day. And while she sings about wanting her dreams to come true, it's clear that she wants to escape her situation and not necessarily find a Prince. The prince in this story is the one who lacks any agency. He's just introduced by this huge and quite funny portrait, and then he falls in love with her. Another fun part about the movie is that there's this whole subplot of the conflict between Lucifer and the mice, which adds nothing to the story of the film but is entertaining nevertheless. Apart from the character of Cinderella, the best part about the movie is the animation. While it lacks the Baroque details of Pinocchio, it is full of brilliant moments. First, the colors really pop out of the screen like it's a watercolor painting but more vibrant. There are these great sequences - for example, one where Cinderella is singing, and you can see her reflection in the bubbles - and yet another where her evil stepmother is in the darkness, and she opens her eyes, and they're this evil shade of green. Great one thing that might be a little bit better is the way that the faces of Cinderella and the prince are drawn when they're dancing together, to try and emulate the styles of actors and actresses at the time the movie was made, and it feels a little bit strange. I am trying to watch all the Disney films in chronological order and I have to say I really like this one and that was a surprise. It's no doubt my favorite.

title: Wrong emphasis, good only for little kids
content: It may seem blasphemous to say that Disney didn't properly handle a classic fairy tale, but I think it's true in this case. The emphasis on the cute talking animals is all wrong. This is supposed to be a story about Cinderella, not talking mice, etc. Bibbidi Bobbidi Boo is a cute song, and A Dream Is A Wish is nice (it doesn't mention love at all), but they do not convey the true romantic element that is crucial to the story. The prince is given practically no character development. She's supposed to fall in love with him because he dances and is a prince? That's it? What really made up my mind about the Disney effort is watching the 1965 TV version with Lesley Ann Warren. The Rodgers and Hammerstein songs in it are magnificent, truly conveying the romantic passion, desire and love of a man and a woman for each other, as well as the romantic idealism of the story. The Disney songs can't hold a candle to them. The prince is given good character development. We see HIS loneliness and desire to find his true love. We see that he is kind and gracious and thoughtful and gentle. He is given a scene where he expresses a desire not to be seen as a "prize" to be won, but a man to be loved. The 1965 version is the timeless classic for all hopeless romantics. The Disney version is for the little kiddies wanting to see something cute.

title: Another example of animated boredom from Walt Disney Pictures
content: The truly best years of animation production at Walt Disney Pictures were while Walt Disney was alive but the horribly dismal results of this film gives an indication of how really bad it is over there today. There's just not much to keep "Cinderella" going in levels of interest as it is just an animated rehash of a story that has been filmed and written way too many times. This film's only highlight and mild levels of amusement comes from Gus and Jaq, Cinderella's two pet mice (these Walt Disney Pictures fairy tale adaptations usually add a couple of new characters in an effort to be more interesting and original). They provide this film's very few good moments with their antics.

title: Disney's 1950 comeback success builds upon the fairy tale success Snow White without re-inventing the core appeal
content: Cinderella having lost her father at a young age grows up under the abuse her stepmother and stepsisters who delight in berating her and treating her like a scullery maid. When the King grows weary of his son, The Prince, putting off a proper wife, the king has his Grand Duke arrange for a ball to be held celebrating the Prince's return and inviting all the kingdom's eligible maidens in the hopes that at least one will catch his interests. Cinderella's friends, the mice and birds of her home, help refurbish a dress belonging to Cinderella's mother using abandoned articles around the home. When Cinderella prepares to go to the Ball her stepsisters violently destroy her dress and cruelly leave her behind. While initially despondent, Cinderella's spirits are lifted with the visit of her Fairy Godmother who performs a spell that will give her all she needs to attend the ball until midnight when the magic ends. Upon arrival to the ball, Cinderella immediately catches the attentions of the Prince which invokes the delight of the king and the Ire of Cinderella's stepmother who is taken aback by this seemingly familiar mystery woman.Released in 1950, Cinderella marked the first feature length single narrative from Walt Disney Animation since 1943s Bambi. The failure of Pinocchio, Fantasia, and Bambi due to the market cutoffs of World War II was a strenuous time for the studio that resorted to making "package films" out of necessity not only to wartime resource scarcity, but also creditors who dissuaded more ambitious projects during this time. With Disney studio debts significantly reduced the company was given the leeway it needed to produce a film of the same scope and ambition of its earlier films which resulted in Cinderella which became Disney's highest grossing film since Snow White in 1937 and helped to keep the company afloat and allow Walt Disney to pursue more projects including Disneyland, film distribution as well as production, and even enter into television. While Cinderella's credit in keeping Disney afloat cannot be overlooked, it also helps that the movie is just really charming with a strong story and likable characters.Cinderella takes everything originated in Snow White and expands and refines it while keeping that same emotional core that resonated in 1937. Cinderella is much like Snow White a good hearted person who's lorded over by a cold and bitter stepmother who spoils her own daughters rotten. While the film follows the similar beats to Snow White in terms of its arc and structure, the movie engages the audience by expanding the scale of the story with a more grand scale than seen in Snow White by making the kingdom and environment feel more alive and tangible than they were in Snow White which went for a more scaled down approach. The scenes in Cinderella's home, the grand scale scenes in the ball at the castle, or even scenes done from the point of view of Cinderella's mouse and bird friends give a larger than life feeling to this kingdom that can't help but draw you in.Outside the technical the film is amazing with a large set of memorable characters who are beautifully animated and given personalities and identities just as big and imposing as the scenes they inhabit. Cinderella while still a very basic good natured, kind hearted Disney princess is a welcome step in building upon what was established with Snow White as she's a much more active protagonist here in her plans for attending the ball (even if they're ultimately undone by the stepsisters cruelty) and conveying a level of subdued humor to herself at the expense of her step sisters and Lucifer the cat that she uses to keep her spirits up. Much of Cinderella's appeal is not only due to her great design and animation, but also to some terrific voice work by her actress , Ilene Woods.The rest of the supporting cast are equally good with Eleanor Audley wonderfully cast as the wicked stepmother, Lady Tremaine whose voice oozes with cold hearted contempt and makes a great villain we love to hate. Likewise the two stepsisters are appropriately obnoxious and harsh and walk the line of being hateful but also allowing us to laugh at their spoiled vanity. The interplay between The King and The Grand Duke is also quite impressive and leads to some great comic back and forth between the two characters, made all the more impressive by the fact they're played by the same voice actor, Luis Van Rooten, who gives them two distinctive voices that are perfectly synchronized. The weakest element of Cinderella is, like in Snow White, the Prince himself. The Prince when he meets Cinderella it's done from a distance focusing on the discussion between the Grand Duke and the King while we don't hear the exchange between Cinderella and the Prince before they dance the waltz. We do get some very basic information about the Prince in one scene where he expresses surprise that Cinderella danced with him not knowing he was the Prince in contrast to the other women at the ball, but it's possible I'm reading WAY more into that than the filmmakers ever intended. This is admittedly a minor criticism all things considered, but still worth addressing as it's the one element taken from Snow White that feels like it wasn't elaborated upon while everything else was.Cinderella is fine escapist entertainment for pretty much anyone. It's the definition of correctly done wish fulfillment with a simple plot populated by larger than life characters and an emotional core that resonates in all the right ways. The animation par for the course is still top notch, building upon the elegance and grace seen in Snow White and refined with the 13 years of experimentation and advancement since. Some elements such as the Prince's lack of defined character don't match the other advances seen in the film, but taken as a whole Cinderella is one of those movies that's guaranteed to end with you feeling happy.

title: Bibbidi-Bobbidi-BEAUTIFUL!
content: Legendary movie producer Walt Disney brought three of the world's greatest fairy tales to the screen. They remain among the most popular animated films of all time. The first was his groundbreaking classic "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" released in 1937. The last was the then-under appreciated "Sleeping Beauty" which made it's debut in 1959. In between these two was perhaps his most satisfying adaptation of a classic fairy tale: "Cinderella" (1950). Of the three films, "Cinderella" is the one most faithful to its origins. Ironically, unlike "Snow White", which for better or worse, became for many the definitive version of the story. "Cinderella" did not follow the same path. Although it was a hit and, like "Snow White", was responsible for restoring the dwindling Disney fortunes, it never achieved the same audience recognition which it certainly deserved. Disney, for once, did himself proud, electing not to tamper with a classic, instead elaborating and adding substance to the tale, rather than rewriting it for the screen. The result was enchanting.A combination of superb animation (in beautifully soft Technicolor) and the perfect voice talents brought the story to life with a radiance that endures to this day. Ilene Woods, who was a radio performer, recorded demonstration discs of the songs as a favor to the authors of the material, Al Hoffman, Mack David, and Jerry Livingston. When Disney heard them, he knew he had found his Cinderella. And indeed he had. Woods heartfelt renditions of "A Dream Is A Wish Your Heart Makes", "So This Is Love" and "Oh Sing Sweet Nightingale" are perfect. Eleanor Audley, who would go on to voice Maleficent in "Sleeping Beauty", masterfully captured the icy cruelty of the stepmother, while Rhoda Williams and Lucille Bliss were convincingly nasty stepsisters. Luis Van Rooten admirably performed as both the King and the Grand Duke, and James Macdonald was endearing as both Jaq and Gus, Cinderella's devoted mice. William Phipps has little dialog as the prince (future talk show host Mike Douglas provided his singing voice) but film (and Disney) veteran, Verna Felton was born to play the fairy godmother, and she made the best number, (the Oscar-nominated "Bibbidi-Bobbidi-Boo") her own show-stopper.Among the artists responsible for the "look" of the film, was Mary Blair, whose inspired use of color was greatly admired by Disney. Her elegant French-period backgrounds add tremendously to the quality of the movie. But, most important of all' are the believable characters--from Cinderella, right down to Lucifer, the stepmother's deliciously evil cat. They bring both life and vibrancy to the often told story, something very difficult to create in an animated film.

title: Bravo to Disney
content: As a young boy, I always sort of hated "Cinderella," since I was outvoted by my two sisters when my parents were considering what Disney movie to buy. I wanted "Dumbo," but my sisters won out, and we got "Cinderella." They thoroughly enjoyed the movie while I sulked in the back of the room playing with my Star Wars action figures.A lot has changed since then. My love of the Disney theme parks landed me an internship at Walt Disney World, and I now have two young nieces. I like to showcase Disney to them as much as I can, and we recently watched "Cinderella" together. With my newfound appreciation for all that is Disney, I watched "Cinderella" with a new perspective and was impressed with what I saw.From the beginning of the movie, though, I didn't quite understand why Cinderella was trapped in such a horrible predicament. Why was she such a slave to her stepfamily, and why couldn't she just run away? I wasn't too sympathetic to Cinderella, but as the story progressed, I found myself becoming immersed in the story. Maybe the eye-catching animation or the fun-loving characters drew me in, or maybe it was the timeless songs. Listening to songs like "Bibbidy-Bobbidy-Boo" and "A Dream is a Wish Your Heart Makes" sort of whisked me back to the theme parks. I can picture myself in that carefree and fun atmosphere while looking at the awe-inspiring Cinderella Castle.Something about this movie just evokes the magic of Disney. That may make many people scoff, but go to the Magic Kingdom and see all the little girls dressed up like Cinderella that are excited to be in this fantasy world, and you'll know what I'm talking about. The images of Cinderella and the glass slipper - as well as Mickey Mouse, Winnie the Pooh, and Tinkerbell - embody why Disney is one of the most beloved companies in the entire world.While "Cinderella" may not be the strongest story, it is sort of iconic in Disney and movie history. It represents that fun, idealistic, and fantasy-like wonderment we held when we were kids. I imagine this movie holds a lot of meaning to many, many people out there. It may not be my favorite Disney movie, but it does represent all that I love and admire about the Company.My IMDb Rating: 10/10. My Yahoo! Grade: A (Outstanding)

title: A Little Faith, a Little Magic, and a Timeless Classic
content: If there's one fairy tale that perfectly captures the classic Disney spirit, it's "Cinderella." Released in 1950, the film marked a triumphant comeback for the studio after the tough years of World War II, establishing itself as a landmark in animation and securing the company's financial survival. But more than just a commercial success, "Cinderella" is a masterclass in cinematic storytelling, striking the perfect balance between emotion, humor, and visual enchantment. It follows a traditional fairy tale structure, sure, but what makes it special is the sheer sophistication of its execution.The story is simple but effective: Cinderella lives under the rule of her cruel stepmother, Lady Tremaine, and her spoiled stepsisters, Drizella and Anastasia. Despite the daily mistreatment, she remains kind and hopeful, finding comfort in the friendship of the household animals. Meanwhile, on the other side of town, the King wants his son to find a wife, so he throws a royal ball where every eligible young woman in the kingdom must attend. Naturally, Cinderella wants to go, but her family sabotages her. Enter the Fairy Godmother, who turns a night of despair into a magical event that will change Cinderella's life forever.The film truly shines in how it builds its protagonist. Contrary to what some might think, Cinderella isn't a passive character. Within the limits of her reality, she resists in the only way she can-by holding onto her dignity and hope. The scene where her first chance at happiness is brutally taken away-the dress ripped to shreds-is one of the most emotionally devastating moments in classic animation. And this is where Cinderella's strength really comes through: her journey isn't just about finding the prince, but about proving that her kindness and resilience are more powerful than the cruelty surrounding her.Lady Tremaine is a formidable villain. Unlike the witches and sorceresses of other fairy tales, she doesn't need magic to exert control. Her power comes from psychological manipulation, from the cold, calculated way she crushes any trace of happiness in her stepdaughter's life. Eleanor Audley voices her with chilling subtlety, making her one of Disney's most memorable antagonists. Meanwhile, Drizella and Anastasia serve as comic relief, leaning into their arrogance and stupidity while still maintaining a mean streak.The film's humor is another one of its biggest strengths. The constant battle between the mice-especially Jaq and Gus-and the cat Lucifer adds an energetic dynamic that balances out the darker parts of the story. These scenes, with a vibe reminiscent of "Tom & Jerry," work not just as comic relief but also as a way to strengthen Cinderella's bond with her little allies.Visually, "Cinderella" is breathtaking. Even with the limitations of the 4:3 format of the time, the film creates a grand sense of scale, whether through the imposing set designs or the fluidity of the animation. The character designs are flawless, with each one standing out visually and personality-wise. The transformation scene, where the Fairy Godmother gives Cinderella her iconic sparkling blue gown, remains one of the most magical moments ever animated-a true testament to the brilliance of Disney's legendary "Nine Old Men."The soundtrack is another standout element. From "A Dream Is a Wish Your Heart Makes" to "Bibbidi-Bobbidi-Boo," the songs aren't just incredibly memorable-they play an essential role in shaping the film's atmosphere. The sweet melodies and hopeful lyrics reinforce the movie's enchanting tone, while Oliver Wallace's instrumental score adds both grandeur and tension in all the right moments.If there's one thing that could've been fleshed out more, it's the Prince. Much like in "Snow White," he functions more as a symbol of the happy ending than a fully developed character. His presence in the story is minimal, and a little more interaction between him and Cinderella could have made their romance more engaging. Likewise, the fact that the glass slipper doesn't turn back to normal after midnight could be seen as a plot convenience-but within the logic of a fairy tale, it's one of those magical details that just work.Overall, "Cinderella" isn't just a well-told fairy tale-it's a timeless film. Its impact on pop culture is undeniable, inspiring countless adaptations and sequels. But more importantly, its message about hope and perseverance remains just as powerful today. It's the ultimate proof that sometimes, all you need is a little faith and a touch of magic to turn even the darkest moments into something extraordinary.

title: Greatest Disney movie ever?
content: Worry not, Disney fans--this special edition DVD of the beloved Cinderella won't turn into a pumpkin at the strike of midnight. One of the most enduring animated films of all time, the Disney-fide adaptation of the gory Brothers Grimm fairy tale became a classic in its own right, thanks to some memorable tunes (including "A Dream Is a Wish Your Heart Makes," "Bibbidi-Bobbidi-Boo," and the title song) and some endearingly cute comic relief. The famous slipper (click for larger image) We all know the story--the wicked stepmother and stepsisters simply won't have it, this uppity Cinderella thinking she's going to a ball designed to find the handsome prince an appropriate sweetheart, but perseverance, animal buddies, and a well-timed entrance by a fairy godmother make sure things turn out all right. There are a few striking sequences of pure animation--for example, Cinderella is reflected in bubbles drifting through the air--and the design is rich and evocative throughout. It's a simple story padded here agreeably with comic business, particularly Cinderella's rodent pals (dressed up conspicuously like the dwarf sidekicks of another famous Disney heroine) and their misadventures with a wretched cat named Lucifer. There's also much harrumphing and exposition spouting by the King and the Grand Duke. It's a much simpler and more graceful work than the more frenetically paced animated films of today, which makes it simultaneously quaint and highly gratifying.

title: Pure Disney magic
content: Supposedly, Cinderella was the film released in Walt Disney's lifetime he was most proud of. While it's far from the best film released in those days, there's no denying what a delightful, charming film it is. Most of the problems can be found in the plot, which is thin and unfocused, though relatively well paced regardless. The mice get just as much screentime as the human characters; in fact, similar to the Good Fairies in Sleeping Beauty nine years later, an argument could be made for them being the true heroes of the film. With that said, despite all the padding in their scenes, they have likeable personalities, and the scenes with them and the family's cat have a certain Tom and Jerry-esque quality to them that gets a ton of laughs.While the mice are the most consistently entertaining part of the movie, the human characters are, for the most part, still entertaining in their own right. Cinderella is a massive step up from the previous Disney Princess, Snow White, as she actually has a personality outside of just being nice. She isn't that way all the time; she has her limits and knows when to stand up for herself. With that said, she's still very charming and held up by Ilene Woods' excellent voice acting. The Stepmother meanwhile is an enjoyably despicable villain, managing to wield absolute control over our heroine with little else than a hard voice and a cold stare. The stepsisters are funny side villains, and the King, Grand Duke, and Fairy Godmother are great too. The only weak character is, of course, the Prince. He has no personality, almost no dialogue, and the romance with the lead is so rushed it's practically an afterthought. He might as well not even be in the film, he leaves so little impact.Some errors aside (watch the Stepmother's eyes; they switch between having pupils and not throughout), this is classic Disney animation that is sorely missed. The character designs are charming and fitting for their personalities. And for the small story, there's a decent amount of size and scope to the film. This is especially noticeable during the scenes with the mice, as we see the house from their POV, making everything seem huge and grand. The scenes at the palace are impressive too, especially during the ball, where the colors are allowed to go crazy and really pop. And of course, the film has a plethora of classic songs that we all know and love, my personal favorite being "Bibbidi Bobbidi Boo". There is a lyric in the mice's song that hasn't aged well, though, and Cinderella's main song gets one too many reprises.Overall, Cinderella does have its flaws, but most of them are minor and, to be honest, I barely notice them while watching it. I'm too busy being engrossed and enjoying myself. Yes, I still maintain that the remake is better, but that doesn't diminish how wonderful the original is.

title: Tremendous comeback
content: In 1950 Disney finally returned to full feature animations with Cinderella, one of their greatest comebacks to date. A film that quite literally saved Walt Disney Animation Studios and allowed them to continue shaping our childhoods.It's also the first fairytale film Disney had produced in a long time, featuring only the second Disney princess at the time of its release. A film of many returns and a film that helped to solidify what a Disney film was to mean.And it's a fantastic film in its own right. The animation is once again some of the best ever made, which must have been a true treat for the audiences at the time after a full half of a decade of nothing but shorts of varying quality. Here the quality is topnotch, though we still have a few films to go before Disney would once again start to push the medium forward with Sleeping Beauty.The story is of course a classic, and nowadays the version almost all think of when they hear the name Cinderella. Disney has always been at its best when it's doing adaptations, this being no exception. The best parts of the original fairytale are transformed into the silver screen experience we've all come to love.If I had to name one problem, I have to admit that the mice are a bit annoying now that I'm an adult. As a child I don't remember minding them at all, but now... Oh well, it's no like they ruin the film, so it's a minor flaw.Cinderella is an important film in Disney canon. It's also one of the better Disney films ever made. A true classic, and if for some reason you haven't seen it already, please do.

title: Must-watch for both fans of classic cinema and lovers of fairy tales
content: The Cinderella story has been adapted into numerous animated films over the years. One of the most popular and well-known animated adaptations is Disney's "Cinderella," released in 1950. This classic film tells the story of a young girl named Cinderella who is mistreated by her stepmother and stepsisters but gets the opportunity to attend the royal ball with the help of her fairy godmother. It is a tale of hope, magic, and the power of true love.Disney's "Cinderella" became an instant hit and is considered a timeless classic. It features memorable songs like "A Dream is a Wish Your Heart Makes" and "Bibbidi-Bobbidi-Boo." The film received critical acclaim and has since been cherished by generations of viewers.In addition to Disney's version, there have been other animated adaptations of the Cinderella story. For example, "Cinderella" was also produced as a direct-to-video animated film by Jetlag Productions in 1994. There are several other lesser-known adaptations as well, each with their own unique interpretations of the classic tale.Title: Cinderella (Older Version) - A Timeless Fairy Tale with Enchanting CharmReleased decades ago, the older version of the Cinderella story remains a cherished classic that has captured the hearts of audiences for generations. This enchanting film, filled with timeless charm, showcases the enduring appeal of the fairy tale.Directed with grace and elegance, the movie transports viewers to a world of magic and wonder. The visual elements, despite the limitations of the era, are still able to create a captivating ambiance. The opulent ballroom scenes, the intricate costumes, and the enchanting set designs immerse the audience in a storybook realm.At the heart of the film lies the beloved character of Cinderella. Played with grace and innocence, she embodies the quintessential fairy tale princess. Her unwavering kindness, resilience, and belief in the power of dreams make her a relatable and inspiring protagonist. As viewers witness her transformation from a mistreated servant to a radiant belle of the ball, they are reminded of the timeless message that goodness and inner beauty will triumph over adversity.The supporting cast members, from the wicked stepmother to the endearing animal companions, each bring their own distinct personality to the screen. The stepmother, in particular, is a memorable antagonist, oozing with wickedness and jealousy, making the audience eagerly anticipate her eventual downfall. The charming Fairy Godmother, with her whimsical demeanor and magical abilities, adds an extra layer of enchantment to the tale.The film's pacing may feel slower compared to contemporary movies, but it allows for a deeper exploration of Cinderella's journey. The moments of tranquility, such as Cinderella singing and interacting with her animal friends, provide a sense of calm and respite amidst the turmoil of her life. These quieter moments contribute to the overall fairy tale atmosphere and emphasize the power of hope and resilience.Furthermore, the film's memorable musical numbers are filled with catchy tunes that have become classics in their own right. From the iconic "A Dream is a Wish Your Heart Makes" to the lively "Bibbidi-Bobbidi-Boo," the songs complement the narrative and evoke a sense of whimsy and joy.The older version of the Cinderella story may lack some of the technical advancements and visual effects of modern cinema, but its charm and timeless appeal have stood the test of time. It continues to captivate audiences with its magical storytelling, relatable characters, and enduring themes of love, kindness, and the power of dreams. If you haven't experienced this cinematic gem, it is a must-watch for both fans of classic cinema and lovers of fairy tales alike.

title: Enchanting.
content: Walter Disney was not a great animator himself, but a great innovator and caterer to what people loved most about life, and the good things life has to offer. He made his films always with this regard at the forefront. From Snow White, to Bambi, Dumbo and all of the other classic tales that he lifted from folklore and history, and, like a deity of animation, breathed life into characters that were once trapped on pages in library books."Cinderella" is no different, and we see a gentle and simple tale of honesty come forth as the young girl who means no harm to anyone must overcome adversity aimed at her in the form of jealousy. An active attempt to keep her down and in her place as we see a contest of power among sisters in name only. There is almost a kind of Jane Goodall quality as we see the new matriarch push aside the offspring of the father's previous love so that her brood can benefit from the resources created by the previous marriage.Cinderella, the once much loved daughter of the household, is now relegated to servitude. But even here her spirit cannot be quelled. For in her labor lies love, and her friends, the various fauna that populate the household grounds and walls, keep her spirits up. She is isolated from people and society, but soldiers on.It is a basic story telling of how seeking consolence from another object of affection can adversely effect that which one loves; i.e. the father remarrying someone whose motives are less than altruistic. But, in the end, it is the stalwartness of the royal seneschel who knows only that his duty must be performed at the behest of the crown, for therein lies honor. And it is thus that Cinderella sees that her one moment to shine has been rewarded through an artifact of military etiquette.It's a lovely film to watch and see. There're no real deep messages, but the story reminds us that delving hastily into new relations where matters of the heart are concerned, can be perilous if the previous party has been wounded. But, it also shows us that it is trusting your heart that brings about, for lack of a better term, good things. It is a story that reminds us that opportunists may crush that which we hold dear, and unless a miracle is forth coming, the likes of which Cinderella experienced, bad things may continue to persist.Technical notes; lots of inbetweens to show us animation so smooth that nothing has been rendered like since CGI, and even CGI comes across as highly mechanical and precision oriented, a raw juxtaposition from the innate intuition of the artists who animate with gentle feeling. This is what makes Cinderella such a beautiful visual for us to sit, watch and absorb.I feel like I should have more to say, but, other than the fact that it's a wonderful film, I'm at a loss for words. Watch it, and enjoy.

title: Stays very true to the original story
content: An other reviewer says that Disney's Cinderella stays very close to the original story and I have to agree with that. I don't think any other Disney fairy tale stays that true to their origins. What Disney does is merely elaborating on the story and adding some helpful animals (especially mice) so Cinderella is not that alone in her duty to face the evil stepmother and stepsisters. I remember reading a Cinderella version where she did get help from birds, so maybe that idea wasn't fully copied from Snow White. The whole story is executed as it should be with a few extras but I must say the movie is kind of lacking in the humor department. It only becomes a bit funny when the mice are in it. The rest of the movie is serious and dramatic. But that's just how the real fairy tale is, pretty dark and dramatic. That doesn't take away the animation is splendid and the magic when the fairy godmother shows up is fantastic. Long had I waited to see this movie for the first time (over 12 years old), not because I disliked the Cinderella story (in fact I love it) but I could not think a fairy tale with so little action (most takes place in the house) could actually make a good movie. I was wrong there. Even if I liked its sequels more I think this one deserves an 8, my only complaint that it lacks humor but I cannot find any faults in the storyline or its execution. I might not have liked it that much first time around but this one needed re-watching to make it grow on me and it did.

title: Great animation, sure.  Great film?  Hardly.
content: "Cinderella" was one of the breakthrough films of its time, with some great animation work.  However, I hardly see it as a "classic fairy tale".  It's certainly not a very inspiring story.  What lesson does it teach?  Stick around through suffering which you have no right to suffer, and your fairy godmother will come and save you.  If you're going to show it to your kids, try waiting it out a bit until he, she, or they are old enough to distinguish between fantasy and reality.  That, or hope that you're a darn good parent.
